case_name: Trade Union v. Ghatge Patil Transports Private Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 437 of 1966 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal NO. 437 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 31,

facts.text: Appeal against award dated March 31, 1964 of Industrial Tribunal Maharashtra in Reference IT No. 40 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated March 31, 1964 of the Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra in Reference  IT  No. 40 of 1963.

facts.text: Reference made by Government under section 10(1)(d) of Industrial Disputes Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the award dated March 31, 1964 of the Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra in a Reference by Government under s. 10 1  d  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

facts.text: Appellant is Trade Union established on January 1, 1962 by employees of Ghatge Patil Transports Private Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Trade Union established on January 1, 1962 by the employees of Ghatge Patil  Transports  Private Ltd. and the respondent is the Company.

facts.text: Respondent Company has registered office at Kolhapur and engaged in transport and removal of goods by road.

anchor.surface_text: The Company has its registered office at Kolhapur and is engaged in the transport and removal of goods by road. It operates on a large scale owning at the material time as many as 70 trucks

facts.text: Company owns 70 trucks at material time.

anchor.surface_text: It operates on a large scale owning at the material time as many as 70 trucks and plies them from Kolhapur  where the registered office of the Com- pany is situate  to far off places such as

facts.text: Company plies trucks from Kolhapur to Bombay, Poona, Bangalore, Goa and Madras.

anchor.surface_text: and plies them from Kolhapur  where the registered office of the Com- pany is situate  to far off places such as Bombay, Poona, Bangalore, Goa and Madras.

facts.text: On January 14, 1963, Union served notice of demand upon Company asking for abolition of newly introduced contract system.

anchor.surface_text: On January 14, 1963, the Union served a numberice of demand upon the Company asking for the abolition of a newly introduced companytract system for the running of vehicles.

facts.text: Company previously employed 70 drivers and equal number of cleaners for operation of trucks.

anchor.surface_text: For the operation of its trucks the Company was previously employing 70 drivers and an equal number of cleaners.

facts.text: On January 8, 1963, Company advertised in local newspaper of Kolhapur trucks for sale and on contract system.

anchor.surface_text: On January 8, 1963, the Company advertised in a local newspaper of Kolhapur that it had trucks in working companydition for sale and also trucks in working companydition to be given for plying on a companytract system.

facts.text: 54 drivers applied for contracts having resigned their service as drivers.

anchor.surface_text: As many as 54 drivers applied for obtaining companytracts having resigned their service as drivers.

facts.text: Company entered into agreements with 54 drivers between January 9 and 31, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Company then entered into agreements with these drivers between January 9 and 31. Each driver received one motor truck for operation according to the terms of the agreement.

facts.text: Each driver-operator received one truck paying Re. 1 per mile to Company; Company supplied fuel, oil, tyres etc.

anchor.surface_text: For our purpose it is sufficient to say that the Company let to these former drivers  to whom we may refer as operators  a truck each on companydition that they paid the Company Re. 1.00 per mile for its use. The Company on its part undertook to supply fuel, oil tyres, tubes, etc. for the purpose of running the vehicle.

facts.text: Operators required to give priority to goods entrusted by Company.

anchor.surface_text: Under this agreement the operator was at liberty to canvass for goods and transport them but he was required to give the utmost priority to the goods entrusted to the Company for transport.

facts.text: Motor Transport Workers Act 1961 passed on May 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The above move by the Company was necessary  so the Company admits  because of the passing of the Motor Transport Wor- kers Act, 1961, on May 20, 1961.

facts.text: Company admits it was impossible to implement conditions of Motor Transport Workers Act for drivers.

anchor.surface_text: The Company frankly admitted at all stages that it was impossible for it to implement all the companyditions of the Act in respect of the drivers of motor vehicles.

facts.text: Dispute referred: contract system must be abolished; ex-employees reinstated with back wages.

anchor.surface_text: The matter of dispute referred to the Tribunal was-- The companytract system for the running of vehicles which has been newly introduced, must be abolished immediately. Such ex-employees of the Company who have been given this work on companytract basis should be reinstated with back wages.

facts.text: Tribunal held drivers voluntarily resigned, not coerced.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal companysidered the evidence and came to the companyclusion that the drivers were number companyrced or forced to take this action.

facts.text: Tribunal held agreements fair to operators, not unfair labour practice.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also held that the agreements were simple agreements for transport of goods and were essentially fair to the operators. Of companyrse, there were advantages as well as disadvantages but the employees number being servants were free agents

facts.text: No drivers appeared to complain against new system.

anchor.surface_text: None of the drivers had appeared to companyplain against the new system.

facts.text: Contracts terminable by three days notice on either side.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal also companymented that under the agreements themselves the companytract was capable of being terminated by three days numberice on either side

facts.text: Union contends resignation and contract system amount to unfair labour practice and exploitation.

anchor.surface_text: The argument on behalf of the Union centres round two facts. Firstly, that the resignation of the drivers and cleaners and the setting up of the companytract system amounts to an unfair labour practice and exploitation of labour

facts.text: Company contends operators are free agents who voluntarily resigned; even union office-bearers resigned.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Company the operators are free agents and freely resigned their jobs and the Company points out that even the, office-bearers of the Union were among those who resigned as drivers and entered into agreements to become operators.

facts.text: Many contracts entered after reference made to Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The Company further points out that many of the companytracts were entered into after the, present reference was made to the Tribunal.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds no reason to disapprove Tribunal findings that drivers voluntarily resigned.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the findings of the Tribunal, which we see numberreason to disapprove, it must be held that the drivers voluntarily resigned and entered into the agreements since they apparently companysidered them to be more favourable than the terms of their former employment.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no bar in law to introduction of contract system.

anchor.surface_text: It is also equally true that there is numberbar in law to the introduction of the system.

facts.text: Company prepared to apply Motor Transport Workers Act to its proper employees.

anchor.surface_text: The Company has declared before us that it is quite prepared, if it was number already doing so, to apply and observe the provisions of the Motor Transport Workers Act in respect of its employees proper where such provisions can be made applicable.
This is an appeal by special leave against the award dated March 31, 1964 of the Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra in a Reference by Government under s. 10 1  d  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Section 37, which is in this last chapter, provides that the provisions of the Act shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law or in the terms of any award, agreement or contract of service whether made before or after the commencement of this Act but not so as to take away from a Motor Transport worker an existing benefit which is more favourable than those under the Act or to prevent him from entering into an agreement for better rights and privileges than those given to him by the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Permits agreements providing better benefits than the Act, applicable here as contract system seen as more favourable by operators

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: law to such action. Section 59 of the Motor Vehicles Act companytemplates the transfer of permits with the permission of the Transport Authorities an

anchor.surface_text: The word employed in the definition of Motor Transport worker is not used in the sense of using the services of a person but rather in the sense of keeping a person in ones service. The definition is, of course, made wide to take in all persons working in a professional capacity in an undertaking for running its affairs in any capacity and not only persons employed on wages.

holdings.text: The drivers voluntarily resigned and entered into the agreements since they apparently considered them to be more favourable than the terms of their former employment.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the findings of the Tribunal, which we see no reason to disapprove, it must be held that the drivers voluntarily resigned and entered into the agreements since they apparently considered them to be more favourable than the terms of their former employment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court accepts Tribunal's findings on evidence with no reason to disapprove; drivers chose contracts over employment.

holdings.text: There was no exploitation of the drivers.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter it is difficult to hold that the Tribunal was wrong in its conclusion that there was no exploitation of the drivers.

holdings.text: There is no bar in law to the introduction of the contract system.

holdings.text: Operators are not Motor Transport workers within the definition as 'employed' means kept in service, not independent hirers paying fixed hire.

anchor.surface_text: The word employed in the definition of Motor Transport worker is not used in the sense of using the services of a person but rather in the sense of keeping a person in ones service. The definition is, of course, made wide to take in all persons working in a professional capacity in an undertaking for running its affairs in any capacity and not only persons employed on wages.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'employed' excludes independent contractors paying fixed rate.

holdings.text: The contract system is not analogous to contract labour cases held to be unfair labour practice.

anchor.surface_text: Contract labour was declared in this Court to be an unfair labour practice because the intention was to introduce a middle man to avoid observance of laws and to deny to labour the advantages it had acquired by bargaining or as a result of awards. Such is hardly the case here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes prior precedents: no middleman, voluntary choice by drivers including union leaders.

holdings.text: A person is free to arrange his business to avoid a regulatory law and its penal consequences if without the arrangement there is no proper means of obeying, so long as no law is broken.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle of lawful avoidance applied to restructuring for MTWA compliance impossibility.

holdings.text: Letting trucks on hire does not require permit transfer under Section 59 of Motor Vehicles Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Hiring distinguished from transfer requiring permission.

holdings.text: The Company has done nothing illegal; no interference with Tribunal award.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative from above holdings; upholds Tribunal rejection of demands.
